author: Spencer S.
title: Stop asking yourself "Do I need it?" or "Would they like it?" and just get it already!
content:
Style: Rugged but sophisticated. It's the perfect watch for someone who may want their watch to look classy at work but not too flashy off the clock. It's universal, it works well with any style. Whether you're roughing the outdoors in feet of snow or coming into an important business meeting, it makes a statement.

Practicality: "Do I need this?" I asked myself every time I passed one at a store, saw an ad, or it happened to pop up on Amazon. The answer; yes I do. This has been a game-changer at work and home. As a teacher, my phone is always going off from group texts with other teachers, administrators, parents, advisory members, and more. This allows me to keep in the loop without whipping my phone out in front of my students. I can also use the bevel to quickly contact teachers during plan periods across the building or out of the building to save myself both the walk and the time. It's perfect in all weather conditions. Is it below zero outside and you're bundled up and have a thick pair of gloves on? That's fine, just use the dial or go into your settings and adjust the sensitivity. Is it raining? Still works, and it's water resistant. Two of the biggest features: Find My Phone; for those of you who forget where it is or perhaps it slipped in between the couch cushions and you've looked everywhere else. Second; The silent alarm. You can set alarms that vibrate only so if you want to catch a quick siesta and not oversleep, it's perfect. Not to mention if you have a busy schedule but don't want to have a ringtone going off or to wiggle your phone out of your pocket in the middle of talking to someone, it delivers a discreet vibration that with a simple swipe can be dismissed.

Battery: I haven't charged my watch in almost 3 days and it's at 50% now. The charging dock is wireless, and it can only be charged wirelessly so it's more water resistant. Aside from how fast the watch charges, the dock works as a bedside clock if you don't wear it to bed.

Health: I walk a lot, more than I thought I already did. This watch has surprisingly encouraged me to walk more by syncing it up to my Samsung Health app and competing with friends and in global challenges. The heart rate monitor is also a wonderful feature. Whenever I measured it on my Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge I felt like I should see a doctor about having a heart condition because it was always 90-100 when I read it. However it turns out my heart rate is 50-70 resting and 80-100 when I'm busy at work.

Other hidden features: I added a dog toy squeak sound as a widget on my phone. Why? Because my dog doesn't always come when I call his name. So I just twist the bevel, tap the play button, and he comes running up to me every time. The uses for the Gear S3 are only limited by your imagination.

Customization: The number of free watch faces seems unlimited. I spent 3 days looking through watch faces trying to decide which one I liked most. The wrist band is interchangeable and Amazon carries all kinds from plastic to leather to metal. It's easy to change and they're very secure.

Is it really water resistant?: YES! You can dip your hand into a kitchen sink filled with water and there will be no effect done to the watch. Gone are the days of burying electronics in rice.

My only con: I wish there were more compatible apps, however, it seems like each day there are a treasure trove of new apps I see that can work with the Gear S3, for now it has everything I need. Though teaching app design to my students, I am a person who loves to go through and test out every app I can.

author: Aniello
title: DONT BUY THIS WATCH
content: Please dont buy this watch if you live outside the US,  Samsung dosent provide support so you will have to spend more money if the watch has any issue. I bought this watch on May 2018 and by December 2018 the watch stopped working all of a sudden due to a battery misfuction. I kept the watch in prestine conditions, bought a protective glass for the watch face and a protective cover for the watch itself howver the battery had a factory malfunction. I called Samsung to ask for support with the watch as this was an internal issue due to malfunction and they said that as I lived outside the US I had to pay for the repair. Worst customer support ever.

author: Columbia
title: International Version: Not US Version
content: International version is unacceptable--no Samsung Pay availability.

author: awesome
title: I wanted to like it
content: I wanted to like the watch but it fell short of expectation. Now, whenever I charge, the green light would come on showing that its fully charged, but when I take it off the cradle, it's only 50% charged.

author: Amazon Customer
title: I love it, B U T,.....
content:
I love it,...BUT the instructions suck!!!
If you're not very tech savvy,.... It's hard to figure out how to operate all the functions this watch offers.  I've had to spent a lot of time with the techs at Best Buy to figure out how to receive text messages.  And I can still only read the last incoming text,... all the others disappear?!?  Settings are very touchy.  They don't tell you that it comes with a charger.  I wasted an additional $15 buying a charger, I didn't need.

author: Nigel G
title: Worth buying
content: I love my watch. Just one small complain, I had to try a few times to get a reading from the heart rate monitor it doesn't pick up your heart rate on the first few go but other than that it is a great watch.

author: Carlos Meza
title: Would buy another one in a heart beat.
content: I love my watch. So cool to be able to take a call on it when my phone is meters away. Its durable and has no problem getting wet in the shower. You can set so many features I'm overwhelmed with the product.

author: Boomer
title: Best watch ever
content: I was back and forth so much on this before I purchased the watch. It was a lot of money and I have never had a smart watch. It has small issues like connectivity and it takes it a second to catch up to the correct time when it wakes up but that I can live with. All in all I love this watch. It does so many things and I keep discovering more all the time. Buy with confidence

author: Michael
title: A must have for general tracking and monitoring!
content: This watch is amazing! Only complaint is sometimes the auto workout function says "great workout" when i wasnt working out, using the restroom lol, otherwise this watch is the best!

author: Jack Dallas
title: Not a Practical Watch Due to Battery Limitations;  Now DEAD
content:
Worked OK for a while, meaning It would last almost 8 to10 hours before needing to be charged.  Recent software issues have brought battery life down to just a few hours a day of use before Low Battery warnings and shift to limited functionality imposed in its conservation mode.  Samsung Pay has only worked a few times and you look silly waving your watch near card readers when people are waiting in line.  It is much faster to pull out a credit card.  My watch is just a year old and watch batteries should last longer than that.

Update 2/8/2019:  Completely died.  Now won't hold a charge more than 20 min.  Did all the maintenance with factory resets, rebooting, new software updates, but nothin works.  This watch didn't last even 1 year without major problems and now is dead.  I have watches I bought back in the '60's that still work so this is just a sign that Samsung should stick to making cellphones and refrigerators.  Watches are not something they understand.

author: Tyler
title: Watch Works Well, Sucks your phone always has to be in your pocket though
content: I loved the watch, its look, how it felt and its functions. However, with the bluetooth only version, your phone always has to be with in range or in your pocket and all that happens is you get double the amount of notifications because you get them on your wrist and in your pocket on your phone. It drove me nuts. I sent this back.  If you are getting one of these, get the LTE version so that you can leave your phone at home and just use your watch.  The other real problem that caused me to send this back was because google maps does not work on this watch. you have to download apps that use google maps and its just not the same.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Doesn't measure heart rate properly
content: Great product overall, except it won't measure my heart rate when it goes above 130 beats per minute, which is every fiber I work out and for most of the workout. Therefore it is useless to me. Sending to Samsung for service, but that'll take weeks and I hate waiting, having paid so much for this watch. Plus, support staff was useless, didn't know the product well enough to know how to get the serial number, initially told me I couldn't get service since I didn't keep the box (!), and only pressure from my side got the guy to figure out the key combination to get the serial. In any case, even if they fix it I won't change this review to more than 3 stars, given that this is a brand new product that is malfunctioning. I need Samsung support to tell me "we're sending you a new watch right away, it'll be there in 2 days" for this to have been different.

author: Brian H.
title: Best Smartwatch I've used
content: I've tried almost all Smartwatches from the original Moto 360 to the Apple Watch and the Gear S3 has been the best experience. Battery lasts at least twice as long as any other I've used. The Dial is the best way to control any watch, It is only a matter of time before others adopt this method. Even though this is an older model with the Galaxy watch, I preferred this model because it has the MST Samsung pay instead of only NFC.

author: SavvySecrets
title: My husband loves this watch!
content: We aren't "Apple" people, but we do love some of their gadgets! This Samsung watch has/does everything and it's easy to use (my husband says). Can't beat the price, either!

author: Craig U.
title: If you like using Samsung pay at ANY card reader, THIS is the watch to get!
content: My last watch was a Huawei gen 1 and I loved it. (Despite it's limitations) Read lots of reviews, and did buy another watch before this one, and returned it due to locking up etc. I factory reset that watch 5 times before giving up and sending it back. I've had NO problems with this watch, and was reluctant to switch from Wear OS to Tizen which is why I just didn't buy this one in the first place. Now? I'm very glad I did. Tizen might not have to largest app store, but what's there works really well. I have no regrets now of dumping Wear OS, despite a few paid apps I lost. The watch itself is very fast, no hesitation, few hiccups with connections or anything else. Also, and one of the best things, is my old "range anxiety" (Like having an electric car) is just nonexistent now.  After 12 hours, I typically have 60% or better battery despite running AOD all the time. (Always On Display) If I wear it overnight and turn the brightness down to 2, and turn off the AOD, it will track my sleep and lose only about 3% battery overnight. I use Watchmaker, and two of my designs are pictured. (Search for Ueltzen in the Watchmaker app, my designs are all free) That Watchmaker app is one that kept crashing the other watch I sent back. (Never a problem on my Huawei or Zenwatch) The best thing about this watch is the MST that the new Galaxy (And most other watches) lacks because Samsung decided to remove it from the new version. I can walk up to ANY card reader terminal, even ones at gas station marts in tiny backwoods towns, where the clerk swears "It ain't gonna work!" and before they can finish the sentence, the reader beeps, and I enter my PIN and out comes a receipt. I even used it at a Walmart where I'd left my wallet in the console of the Jeep, and paid with the watch itself, you do NOT have to be near the phone for the Samsung Pay to work! Few clerks or cashiers have seen it before I use it, so it gets a LOT of comments.

author: Wes
title: Awesome product, highly recommend.
content: Awesome product, superior design even in 2019. Maybe a little large of a watch for some people's taste but it's perfect for me. The bezel is awesome and one of the reasons I decided to go with the S3. Battery could be better but cant expect much of a battery inside these smartwatches to begin with so as long as I can get a full days use (checking time frequently responding to notifications and such) I'm happy and this does that no problem so far.

author: Chris
title: The perfect gift to get yourself
content: I've been wanting a smartwatch now for about two years. I'm glad I waited to get the Gear S3 Frontier now that the Galaxy watch came out (heavily discounted). It has much the same functionality as the Galaxy watch except being swim-capable. I don't swim anyway, so it's no big loss. It's full of apps and the sound quality isn't that bad. I made a call on it already and it sounded decent. The voice recognition software on it is a bit sluggish and doesn't always get what you're saying, but I suppose I'll have to toy with it some more to learn the bugs. The vibration is very strong and the volume is loud enough to wake you from a solid sleep. It took me about 20 minutes to fully set it up before I could start customizing and using it (downloading updates, etc.). But, it was extremely easy to pair and set up. It came with a 30% charge already and took less than 45 minutes to fully charge on the supplied wireless charger. I highly recommend getting a screen protector for it (which I did).

author: Guillermo Garcia
title: Great watch
content: Love the watch. Just like described. Has a great battery life and it's great as it let's you control the volume of music and skip or back songs without having to take the phone out of my pocket. Has trouble understanding me sometimes due to my thick accent but otherwise great.

author: McFrosty
title: Love my Gear S3
content: Didn't really expect I'd get into a smart watch as much as I do. Have become attached to it now. I never even wear watches, but I do with this one. Only con I can give is the band. I started to develop a skin inflammation around my wrist after a couple weeks. Solved that by getting a stainles steel magnetic band that works great. The best part for me had been using Samsung Pay. Nice to not even have to break out your debit card-just waive your watch!  I've been very happy with this purchase.

author: Jarod Doran
title: Well worth the money. Don't cheap out
content:
This is the best of all the smart watches. When I was shopping for one. I saw the other brands had a 12hr usage time. I couldn't have that.
This one runs forever. I wear it all day and all night, only charging it for 15-20 minutes in the morning when I shower and it will last 5 days easy, usually longer. Well worth the price. Has all the features you could want, looks and fits amazing. I did get a larger band because I have big wrists, but I knew what was going to happen.  Amazing product.

author: smithriver
title: My husband is really happy with his watch
content: My husband is really happy with his watch, but we DID NOT pick up on the fact that it does not have it's own number like the ones Verizon sells.  It can answer your phone, but you have to have your phone on you.  Just a heads up.

author: Vinoda
title: Can be better
content: The watch was great when I first started using it. Battery drains fast but that's expected. Tracks steps well and it's easy to read messages on the watch. Looks great too. However, one of the updates screwed up the watch making the battery drain like crazy.

author: Richard Batruch
title: the updated app doesn't work unless you have a samsung phone, DONT BUY GEAR WATCHES
content: I have spent hours and hours on the phone with technical support and they can't fix the app, and it appears that they have know about the apps problems for 5 or 6 months and don't tell people before they buy the phone. I have a google pixel 3, and with the old version of the app everything worked just fine, I already had 3 gear watches. The current app that they can't seem to fix gives a blank white screen when you tap to sign into your gear account, and without the gear account being connected, you can't update apps, get any new watch faces get notifications properly or do most of the smart functions you want to work when you spend hundreds of dollars on a watch. I happened to buy two new watches, this gear sport and the new gear watch 46mm. After the tech people on the phone were done with me, not only did the new phones not connect, they had me reset all my other watches, so now I have 5 watches that don't function because they can't fix the app. UNLESS YOU HAVE A SAMSUNG PHONE TO USE WITH IT, DON'T BUY ANY GEAR WATCHES, YOU WILL BE VERY VERY DISAPPOINTED. Samsung should be letting people know, and letting sellers know that they have this problem and have know since at least October of 2018 going by the threads I have found of other people complaining about the problem. I wondered why the prices had dropped so much on these watches, they are great when the app works, without the app there is nothing smart about them, they are just a watch. As far as I am concerned, they are defrauding people buy continuing to sell theses watches and not telling people the smart functions won't work. They had me download and send them log files from my phone and the watches and then I never hear from them again, they have no idea how to fix the problem and screw up peoples phones and watches playing tech support like they do. BEWARE BEWARE BEWARE

author: Klyn newton
title: I want one
content: My husband loves his watch so much hes making me jealous! Brought as a gift, he was absolutely beside himself. Just like having a phone assistant and no way he can't say he "didn't get my text" now lol. Awesome price when I purchased it and looks great on his wrist.

author: Pha101
title: So far a great watch.
content:
Received this a few days ago , setup was really easy with very little learning curve once you start playing with the settings. The super AMOLED screen is simply beautiful and works well even in low light conditions.There is a huge selection of watch faces via the gear app to customize the watch even further.I have read reviews saying that there is not enough app support from Samsung , for me that's really not a problem since I mostly use the watch for notifications , fitness and payments.
The best feature is the Samsung pay which works on non NFC terminals by using MST technology making it far more useful than Android Pay of Apple Pay.

My only issue is the original watch strap that the watch came with , it sticks to the skins if your sweating while working out and that can be little irritating.

author: DANIEL ALBORNOZ
title: Atención inmediata
content: Todo bien, solo que no me gustó estuviesen abiertos los sellos de seguridad y tuviese un detalle el bisel, pero el vendedor me respondió con un descuento. Gracias

author: iRichiFix@gmail
title: If I could make love to this watch, I would!
content: This watch is the balls! Love it! I have done comparisons on the Gear heart rate monitor compared to my Suunto heart rate monitor and they are almost exact. Sometimes they read same and other times they are off 1 beat/min. I have compared the steps taken on my Gear with my wife and daughters fit bit and we are fairly close. I'm taller so I have less steps, but its really close. I have been swimming with the Gear on and haven't had any issues. This watch is highly recommended. Oh, the battery was draining fast at first (lasting just under a day). I performed a factory restore with updates and now I get 2.5-3 days.  The new software updates fixed a lot of issues I see reported in older reviews, so keep that in mind. I bought a few watch faces, but really only use one of them all the time.

author: Fabian L
title: For a 2 years old device, it is very impressive
content:
I love it. I'm a fan of buy all type of intelligent watches. Tried Garmin Forerunner 235, Vivoactive 3, Suunto Spartan, Polar M400 and many more. This is the one I always wanted to have. Very complete. Maybe the fitness tracking is not the best (the dedicate brands are better in GPS, health stats) but this one does fine.
The thing I like most is the screen. Black is black, colors are vivid. I love it. Recommended.

author: Recon
title: Make sure you buy the US version.
content: Love my watch but I bought the international version which doesnt support samsung pay. Realized that it didnt have that feature about a year later after buying the watch. Other than that, gear frontier is a great watch. Has speakers so you can take a call right from the watch.

author: anderson j.
title: NOT GEAR S3 FRONTIER!
content: This item is not the frontier s3. This item is gear sport. Some how the shipping label says frontier s3 but it is not!

author: DaveInPDX
title: Fast performing, great battery, excellent fitness features, And Dick Tracy cool stuff too.
content:
Does what I want in a smartwatch - tells time (always on display active, will ast for 2 days), and an excellent fitness tracker. Add in my reminders & calendar and it is a solid smartwatch. The ability to answer the phone when it is in a pocket/another room whatever, is ultra cool.

Battery: 2 days, easy. On business trips if I forget the charger I can put it in low power mode overnight and it will last several days.

Performance is splendid - Tizen is stable, fast, no lag and I love the bezel for controlling the watch. Way more accessible than Android wear.

Great fitness tracker. finally a watch that has decent heart rate tracking - actually useful - and GPS so it is great for bike rides & running. When I go out & garden or take a walk it will automatically detect activity, so more than just steps, it records activities AND floors climbed, so you can see how active you were throughout the day or week.

Apps: I never used many with Wear, and here I have what I need: Contacts, calendar, fitness, time & date, answering the phone. Has Spotify, and I can move my podcasts here easily (as mp3), though I would like a featured podcast manager.

Android Pay with the phone was a PITA, using Samsung pay with the watch is 1) way faster/trouble free and 2) works at far more places than Android or Apple pay.

author: Nakore
title: Bought used. Was like new.
content:
I was a bit hesitant when I purchased this. I purchased it "used" here from Amazon. In the end, I bought it used because it was sold by, and shipped by, Amazon. I have yet to have a problem with Amazon standing behind anything. It said, that being used, it could have blemishes, could be in non-original packaging, etc.

I'm sure mileage varies, but I scored!! Other than I could tell the package had been opened and re-taped, it looked brand, spanking, new and in perfect condition!!

As a watch, it's OK. It isn't as useful as I had hoped for handling notes, lists, etc. because the screen is so small. And (there may be a way to fix this, but I haven't found it) it is quite annoying if I cross my arms across the face of the watch. It detects it as a "long press", and will often change the watch face!!

It is also a bit annoying if you use a lot of non-Samsung apps. Unless those apps come with a widget for the watch, you might as well not have the watch. For example, I have for years used an alternative text messaging app. Once I got this watch, I had to switch back to the default message app for it to interface with the watch.

I still give it full stars because it does exactly what it claims to do. It isn't the fault of the watch that my favorite apps don't offer watch widgets.

I'd still like to find a way to stop that arm crossing long-press problem, though.

author: spook
title: best upgrade i ever made
content: i just got my watch today 3.10.2017!!! best upgrade i ever made! i only had the gear s i did not upgrade to the gear 2 because that was like downgrading but with the frontier works for me even though i went with the Bluetooth version i still got to answer calls without my phone. the fitness app on the watch is better than on gear s3 than gear s overall barny (how i meet your mom show) was right newer is better!!

author: cptcavemn76
title: the watch is just Bad A**, but Samsung charges for all the cool ...
content: Well, the watch is just Bad A**, but Samsung charges for all the cool stuff including the main reason why I got it, the GPS!!!

author: C. Sutherland
title: Looks great!  Feels great!
content: Just received this today but already love it!!  If it holds up under the paces I’ll put it through then I’ll be impressed!  Synced immediately with my iPhone 7 Plus.  Watch is a little heavier than I hoped for but still feels great....and the negative reviews on the watch band hurting wrists....Samsung must have upgraded this feature as I feel no discomfort at all.

author: Photostar
title: Best Smart Watch on the Market, Worth the Wait
content:
Waited a few weeks to write this review. First off, I wanted to like the Gear S2 that came out last year, but some expectations fell flat and I knew the second generation would be worth the wait. Boy was I right!
First off, Style, The Frontier has the rugged mans looking watch that the Classic and Sport didn't offer. I love the way it looks, and there were plenty of watch faces to choose from (I love the one with glowing green luminescent look). The band although easily replaced, looks fine and seems durable.
Battery Life, Charging this watch on every 3rd night before I go to bed. I like to wear it as much as possible to track sleep, and fitness goals. It seems to me that the watch starts to adjust to your "pace" and activity rate to improve accuracy as time goes on. My settings are for watch to be on when I look at it and I dialed down the brightness a tad.
Functionality, I've got this paired with a Samsung Note Edge (a great discontinued phone I hope I never part with), and it's a quite large phone, so having not to pull it out of my pocket every time I get a text, email or a call (from spammers)is a dream come true. I have taken calls on it and all though a little nerdy talking into a watch, the speaker works great and people on the other end hear me quite clearly as long as the bluetooth connection is strong. One time when I had my bluetooth headphones on , I took a call and it went to the watch instead of the headphones. Cycling the power on the bluetooth headphone seemed to transfer it over, but I need to understand how to make it go to the headphones when they are paired.
Notifications are programmable through an APP that you download from the Play Store, so you can turn on or off any notification that originates from the phone. The vibration is just enough to let you know something came in. I believe you can also choose which notification lights the face or just buzzes the watch.
Fitness , I have been a big fan of my Garmin Vivofit for almost 2 years, it as helped me lose weight and stay active. The steps on the Garmin tend to be higher than the watch, but it may be that my stride is not calibrated on the Vivofit. But let's face it, if you shoot for 10,000 steps a day, a few hundred off is irrelevant . Now the Gear actually "talks" to you with notifications, like "get moving" "stretch" and and gives you nice little notifications when you've met your activity or step goal. Heart rate monitor is better than I expected since I have the strap for my Garmin and found that and the watch to be on par with the HR monitor on the treadmill. Wearing the watch tight on your wrist will yield better results. There are some cute apps like USA Today that will tell you the top stories, but to read them, you have to open your phone, which is fine. The watch as the ability to control your music on your phone ( I use rocket player) and there's an app to remotely fire your camera phone from the watch, I'm a photographer, and that's just pretty cool to take stealth photos..Well "Lucy" as a reference to the  Android movie with Scarlett Johansson is what I call her, and she's telling me to "Get Moving" (who am I to argue with SJ?) So I gotta run..or walk.

author: Christine Zablocki
title: Battery Issues with Custom Watch Faces
content: I looked at a lot of different reviews before choosing this watch, and so far am LOVING it!! I really wanted an activity tracker that didn't look like an activity tracker.  It's easy to understand, you can move apps around on the watch, and download apps to it.  I really like the charging station, because it charges the watch vertically on a stand.  My only complaint, and the reason I can't give it 5 stars, is that if you install extra watch faces, that are default faces, it'll be okay at first, then suddenly your watch will go from 100% to 0% in 24 hrs.  In researching the issue, it seems like it's a common one, and Samsung is likely aware of it, and hopefully it's fixed in the Gear S4.  While not a huge inconvenience, as their are plenty of default faces to choose from, it's still disappointing to find a face you really like, then have to get rid of it because it drains your battery.  This issue certainly wouldn't have stopped me from purchasing the watch.  I also have Samsung Health installed and love the tracking it does for me, makes things easy.  Overall, it really is a great watch, and I'm very happy that I decided to purchase it.

author: Adam
title: Serious connection problems
content: This watch was 5 stars for 3 months and then began disconnecting up to 5 times per day.  Samsung recommended uninstalling app and reinstalling.  This led to watch doing a reset.  Pictures lost, music lost, apps lost (some are no longer available).  I've always believed in Samsung products, but this is a terrible product.  It's only as good as the connection.

author: Christopher Messinger
title: Quality Control
content: The watch was a great price however......when it came it wouldnt stay charged for more than 4 hours. I sent a letter to the seller who pretty much told me it was of high quality equipment blah blah and I would have to send it to them so they could be the deciding factor if it was in fact not holding a charge. Whatever I went to a cell phone repair shop and had a new battery ordered and installed for about 50 dollars and now it works like a dream and holds a charge for 2 days.  The watch is a steal for the price however the customer service was horrible or at least how they presented themselves. So...buying used products is a gamble but selling used products there has to be quality control so you can back up your product. No 5 star for you.

author: Wayne Wright
title: Samsung Pay DOES NOT WORK
content:
The watch is great just it is not a US version & Samsung Pay CANNOT BE LOADED!!!!!!!
False advertising
AMAZON should make them pull the description!!!!!!!

author: Doug
title: Very good smart watch that I use everyday!
content: Only downfall to this watch is when sleeping, the watch is a bit big and bulky.

author: Jeff
title: Nice design, poor execution.
content:
Cons:
  * Samsung Pay would not install after I factory reset my phone.  Support has been no help.  Just keeps kicking me between departments.

  * The fitness tracker only catches about 1/2 of my workouts.

  * The charger is bulky and not travel friendly

Pros:
  * Big screen makes reading notifications easy.

In summary, it's a nice gimmick, but I wouldn't buy it again.

author: s&rew
title: Truly Smart Watch
content:
I've got a lot of Samsung tech, so I may be slightly biased towards their stuff. I got this watch replace my Samsung Gear S, I think one of the first generation of smart watches. Basically, that was a extension of the phone. I could answer calls, but neither hear nor talk to the person.
This watch has a built in speaker and microphone, so I've actually heard people talk on the watch, although I still haven't confirmed that it actually works as a second phone - Dick Tracy style (or James Bond, depending on which one you remember).

This watch charges very quickly on the charging pad, and holds its change too. I've lefty it out for three days, it still had 16% left. On an average day, the charge goes to about 80% on a full charge.
The weather functions are an impressive upgrade, although I haven't verified the accuracy of the tools. It appears that some of the tools - altimeter, barometer among them - need a reference to be really effective, but i haven't tested that yet. It looks pretty accurate compared to available data even without the reference.
The health functions are amazing - not only does this watch measure heartbeats accurately and frequently, it does a fair job predicting your current activity - walking, running, biking. I haven't tried swimming with it yet, but I think that's an option - I wouldn't do it without some protection however. The one annoying part of this is that it will prompt you (unless you change the notification settings) to start walking if you're stationary for a long time - not exactly a good idea of you're sitting in a meeting. It will also buzz if you're walking around at work, just a casual reminder that you're also exercising.
As a timekeeper, it's pretty good. Oddly, with all of the fancy apps on this thing (you can download more through the gear os on your phone), a good free chronometer is hard to find. Nonetheless, it does its primary job very competently.
I'm hopeful that with updates, this watch will keep getting better and smarter.

author: Warren Harris
title: I really like this watch
content: I really like this watch.  It's pretty easy to configure and use.  I love the fact that I get updates from apps on my phone and can decide whether I need to pursue them, leave for later or delete the notifications right on the watch.  It's great for tracking exercise and health stats in general.  Nice feel, navigation and design.  I added a metal band, as I don't like the silicone, but that's a personal choice.

author: Austin C.
title: Does your wife not bug you to exercise enough?
content: If not you need to get this watch. Other than tell them time on it I only use it to remember to do torso twists every 30 minutes or so. Sometimes I send a generic reply to a text with it and feel like a secret agent but otherwise I don't use alot of the features. I'm sure others take more advantage of theirs...

author: Xavier Ruiz
title: Buena compra.
content: Mejor que su predecesor por el GPS y la opción de contestar llamadas. Un poco pesado para mí gusto, pero te acostumbras a la larga. Un poco más dificultoso hacer deporte con el por el tamaño y el peso. Lo demás, excelente.

author: Fátima
title: Frustrating!
content: I bought this watch for my son and it was frustating to find out after it was delivered that it doesn't come with an U.S. wall power adapter, this was made to some other country with a different kind of plug, although they say it's a US version, its not! That makes no sense to buy an expensive watch if you can not even charge it!!! I have others chargers but they are not compatible with this device! I will definitely return it!

author: LUCK
title: Good Watch, Good Fitness Aid, Lots of Extras
content:
This is a very nice fitness watch and syncs well with my Samsung phone.  It seems to hold a charge for at least 2 days, and probably 3-4 if you use lower-energy settings.

In the end, this is about two things: (1) a watch, and (2) a fitness aid.  This watch does a great job at both of those.

There are lots if nifty features that give it phone-like capabilities (through Bluetooth to your phone, you can make calls, get/send emails/texts).  But I've found I don't really need those.  Nor do I need many of the other extras (games, news, etc).  I just don't want to have my phone be yet another place that I look for that stuff, or yet another place that is beeping at me.

NOTE: Some Samsung Gear S3 watches have full cellular capabilities - they can handle calls, emails and texts even without a Bluetooth connection to your phone.  This unit does NOT have that capability.  Be sure you're buying the right watch!

author: Gordon
title: My first smart watch- IF YOU HAVE TATTOOS READ THIS!
content:
I'll start w/ the look. I love the way the watch looks. Feels sturdy. I have had no issue with the bezel feeling loose like other reviews state. Size is perfect as I dont like small watches but i dont like overly large ones either. The strap it comes with is OK. But I am upgrading as it sweats a lot during workouts.

Functionality wise it's hit or miss for me. The motion function to turn the face on works 80% of the time. I have found myself having to repeat the motion a few times in the 4 days I have worn it. The always on mode does not work for me at all. at first i thought i had a faulty watch. i looked it up online and several people have had the same issue if they have tattoos. I cant grasp why an always on function would be impacted by ink. So I had my wife wear it and it works just fine on her.
Pulse is hit or miss. I'd say it works 50% of the time. on the first try it works about 25% of the time. most times i either have to adjust the watch and try several times or i just give up. This makes a little more sense as far as tattoos impacting it.
Alerts work perfect. battery life is awesome. the charger it comes with works great. the face options are awesome too. you can download a ton.

samsung tech support is HORRID! when i called about the always on issue it took me a while for them to even understand what always on was. I thought maybe i got a new guy on. so i hung up and called back again. same thing. i had to tell them what people were saying on their own boards about the tattoo issues. a quick google search pulls up several threads.... how are you, as the maker, not going to know about a known issue? she had to escalate and said i would get an email confirming that she elevated. never got it. ill wait a few weeks and call back.

I think i will still keep the watch regardless of its issues/its issues bc of my tattoos. overall its a nice watch. i dont know if im too lenient bc its my first or if most smart watches have their own issues. but overall i am ok with spending $300 on something nice w/ some problems.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Great watch, great battery life for a smartwatch.
content:
One week ago, I would have rated this with 5-stars.  However, for some unknown reason, the battery life, which was 3+ days, has gone down to about 8 hours.  I haven't downloaded any apps or changed the settings I have been using for the past month; the only change has been some sort of software update.

I'm giving a temporary 3-stars in hopes that I can figure out a solution.  If I can, I'll bring this up to 5-stars.  If I can't, I'll lower this to 1-star and return it.  Either way, once I figure out what I'm going to do, I'll provide better feedback with what I like and dislike, etc....
====
Update:  So, after the watch completely discharged its battery, and I let it fully charge again, I'm back to a full 3 days of use.  The only setting I changed after it charged was turning the 'connections -> wifi' from 'auto' to 'off'.  I figure I almost always have my phone, and if I don't, I'm probably not near an open access point WITHOUT a captive portal (requiring browser-based login).  That doesn't necessarily explain the battery drain because this was how I had the setting previously.

This is a great watch, based on what I was looking for.  I previously had an LG G watch, one of those goofy-ass rectangular smartwatches, and other than the style, i really liked the functionality.  I like the style of many new round smartwatches, but they were either prohibitively expensive (Tag Heuer), or the battery life was crap (most smartwatches), or, in the case of the LG Watch Sport and Style, you either got more than you wanted and paid for it, or not enough.

My criteria:
Looks (subjective, but essentially, a round smartwatch that wasn't too bulky, but with a screen big enough to use)
Functionality (had to work with a non-Samsung Android smartwatch, show notifications from hangouts, SMS, calendar, etc)
Battery Life (had to very easily make it through 24 hours)
Non-LTE version

I think the watch looks great.  I'm a bigger dude, so the watch doesn't look out of place and huge on my wrist like some of the other photos I've seen.  If you have svelte features, maybe the size would be problematic.  I'm using the standard band that comes with the watch, which looks good, but I like that I can easily switch bands if I want to.

Functionally, the watch is great.  I get notifications from SMS and Hangouts, as well as from Google calendar, which I use at work for upcoming meetings.  Initially, as I was researching the watch, I wasn't sure if a non-Samsung watch would pair well with this, since it doesn't run Android Wear (it runs Samsung's Tizen OS).  The only issue with regard to Tizen is the lack of apps, but I don't really care about extending the capabilities beyond what it already does (wihch is what I need/want).  The watch has decent sensors for 'exercise', though I suspect there are superior watches for that.  I don't exercise that much and don't care about measuring my heart-rate anyway.  I can feel my heart about to explode out of my chest when I play hockey, which is a good enough indicator that I'm getting some exercise.

Battery life is awesome.  I'm currently on my third day since its last charge, and other than the weird drain issue I first wrote about, the watch has been solid.  I do currently have wifi off, as well as location, since I usually have my cell phone nearby; the watch gets that info from the phone.  Knowing I can turn either of those on, if I needed to, is nice.  I also have my watch face set to only turn on when I move my wrist or push a button.  I've read that keeping the display always-on would reduce battery quite a bit.  Good thing I'm not always looking at the watch face.

Bonus features!
Samsung Pay.  I never used Android pay (NFC) for purchases.  I was sort of waiting until it was more ubiquitous and expected, as opposed to everyone looking at you like 'one of those types'.  That's just my own insecurity though.  But with this watch, I just press a button, select a card, and then hold the watch near the card-paying-thingie (NFC terminal) at the store.  That's great and all, but what's really super great is that it doesn't have to be an NFC terminal.  As long as it's got the magnetic strip, this watch will work!  I tried it at a local liquor store and the woman said, "this device is really old and doesn't have that fancy technology."  I replied, "this watch is magic, check this out!".  We were both pretty impressed.

Another feature I really like is how you can reply to messages.  There is an old phone style keyboard, with 2-3 letter per number, which is just terrible.  There is the ability to speak into the watch, which I don't use because nothing comes close to Google's speech recognition, in my option.  And the other option is to draw the letters on the screen.  I wasn't sure how well that would work; it works great!  Just draw each letter, quickly, if you want, with an underscore for a 'space', and then send.  Love it.

Finally, Dick Tracy, you can answer phone calls through your watch.  Just speak into it.  I haven't really used this, and figure I will never use it unless I'm tied to a shark, which is tied to a missile, or maybe if I'm driving (I don't have Bluetooth in my car).  But it's cool.

Anyway, this is a good watch.

author: Joe Boucher
title: Outstanding!
content:
I am a tech guy with a healthy appetite for gadgets. After deicing which phone of mine I should use primarily (Pixel 3XL or Iphone X Max) I decided on the Pixel 3 XL. But....what watch? Finding a replacement that meets the features of the Apple Watch is no easy task. If I could use my apple watch on the pixel, I would!

So, I had a older model LG watch which is just ok. The battery life is dismal with minimum use and barely makes it a day. So, I took a chance with the well reviewed Samsung Galaxy S3. I could have waited for the new ones to come up this fall, but they removed the bezel, which to me is a strong selling point.

I got my S3 and put it to the test. It's big, but yet thin. It doesn't have that Oreo Cooking thickness sitting on my wrist. The colors and clarity are great, and the watch just feels like it was built with quality.

So, how does it compare to the Apple Watch? I would say it is just as good, but in a sightly different way. Getting used to a round face vs. square and larger on my wrist won't be a big deal. The notifications are great. What I like with Samsung is that I can actually change the notification tones on the watch. There are several short tones to choose from that make sure you hear it, but it's not obnoxious.

The Bezel! Best way to navigate a watch. It's fluid, yet precise, so your not going past the screen you want. THe locations of the notifications are to the left, and the widgets to the right.

Battery! Holy Cr@p! 2 day's of use including monitoring my sleep last night, and it's only down to 63%. That beats the battery on the Apple Watch.

Apps: Not as robust as Apple or Wear OS. There are plenty of apps, but Where is the Dark Sky App?

Summary: If you want a watch that lasts a very long time and does the job, this is it.  It takes a lot to impress me, and this watch did. Check out my picture and watch face. Sorry for my hairy arm. Cheers!

author: M. Quick
title: Great watch, lots of features
content:
Great watch, lots of features.  It is a little on the bigger side, so if you have smaller wrists it might be a little oversized.

Pros:
- Great battery life, I just tested it and made to right at 4 days from full charge to 9%, I was not using gps, but had several hour + workouts using live  heart rate monitoring.
- Very good look and feel.  The stainless case and rotating bezel give a really professional, rugged, and classy look to it.  easy to wear in all situations
- Heart rate monitoring.  I actually have had really good luck with the live heart rate monitoring.  keep it tight and off your wrist bone and it picks up fine.
- It can be used with Android or Apple phones.

Cons:
- I have a Galaxy S6 Edge Plus and the Frontier links to it via bluetooth.  The bluetooth being on cuts my battery life in half pretty easily, so while the watches battery is great, it does impact my phone significantly.  If i disconnect it from my phone, then it does lose the notification function when receiving texts/calls.
- It's monitors your sleep patterns, but you have to go through several steps to turn off the notifications, or the wake up gesture before you go to sleep, other wise it lights up in your face all the time.  and regardless what you do if you turn the bezel it still lights up, so kind of annoying.
- S Health app, the main app that tracks all your health and biometrics is a pretty solid app, but it seems to be geared toward the runner/cyclist, which i'm not.  I do a lot of weight lifting and some cardio.  There isn't a real good app for just pulling live heart rate continuously and measuring calorie burn with our constant suggestions to move more or go faster.  (pretty minor, but still a nuisance)
- It can get wet, but it's not recommended to swim with it on.  They do not recommend salt or fresh water swimming, but it is capable of being submerged.

Overall it's a great product, and while a little pricey it's cheaper than a comparable non-smartwatch with similar design.  There's a ton of watch face options available, and apps are being added daily.

author: David Kieras
title: This Watch Luddite has been won over
content:
I always have thought that the watch is the one classic accessory that wouldn't be replaced by a computing device.  I've avoided digital watches in favor of quartz and automatic watches with good old analog time-telling capabilities.  "I've no need to digitize my life any further," said the man.  And I have turned down the Apple watch.  But this old man still can learn new tricks, and this watch really surprised me with its versatility.

Let's be honest: I got this watch because  1) I am an android user,  2) I was taking a 2-week European vacation,  3) it was available on Warehouse Deals for cheap, and 4) I wanted to have the convenience and security benefits of paying with NFC without pulling out my phone.  I really couldn't have cared less about any of the other features.

Suffice it to say that for my intended purpose, the watch worked admirably.  But on the trip, it also gave me information about my steps and actvity which was great.  I could check for messages from my travel mates without pulling out my phone.  The S3 was able to read out my GPS directions so it was less awkward to follow directions while walking.  And I discovered that I could change watch faces at a whim.  Way more than I expected.  And I loved using the rotating bezel as a control.

Now nothing is perfect and that's true with this watch.  To be fair, I gave it the highest rating because it far exceeded my expectations and made me a believer in the usefulness of smart watches.  However, it is important to know these

First, although the stated battery life is 2 days, when you are traveling and using it a lot it's safer to assume 1 day.  There was one day where my charger came apart from the wall and the watch did not charge overnight, so it died half-way though the day.  I feel that there should have been some low battery warnings before it shut off, but I didn't get any.  So that's why I gave only 4 stars on battery life.

Second, the main button of the watch stopped functioning.  However, I made it through the trip and shipped it to Samsung and they repaired it at no charge.  So while it was good that I could function without the main button, it was disconcerting that it broke during the trip.  At any rate, all fixed and all good now, so still a good deal.

Third, you need to note that with your phone constantly in connection with your watch, it is likely that you will see reduced battery life on your phone.  This hit hardest while traveling, and probably was exacerbated by the different networks we were using, but the upshot is that you can put the watch into Airplane mode and make up to 5 purchases before it needs to sync with your phone again.  So unless you are constantly using the watch, then you can do that.  However, then you won't get any notifications.  This shouldn't count against the S3 specifically but I gather will be true of all smartwatches.

Fourth, it may interfere with bluetooth connectivity to your car stereo.  I have had some issues and have found that putting the watch in Airplane mode solves most of them.  I mean, you don't want to check messages or get phone calls on your watch, do you?  Still, a minor inconvenience.

Fifth, although this smartwatch supposedly allows you to use dictation similar to a limited Siri or Google agent, it is way worse with word recognition than the phones themselves.  Almost unusable, IMO.

Again, these shortcomings do not affect my current usage of the watch, but may well prevent adoption of newer features.  In my book, this watch is a home run for Samsung and has changed my mind about smartwatches.

author: C. H. Reinehr
title: SUCH an upgrade over my Asus ZenWatch 2
content:
I purchased the Gear S3 Frontier to replace my ZenWatch 2, and wow is it an upgrade! The watch itself is very sturdy, I love the rotating bezel, and the widgets are great. (I'm using weather, agenda/day calendar, health dashboard, app shortcuts, reminders, and alti-barometer.) I finally found a nice and simple watchface that displays time, date, weather, steps, and sunrise/sunset, AND is customizable. It's a black background with no real visual bells and whistles, and I'm easily getting 50% more battery life than I was before. I could get even more by disabling the Always On Display... but I don't want to. ;)

I've been very impressed with the activity tracker. The moment I've been walking for 10 minutes, it kicks in and starts recording time, steps, and pace. I don't sleep wearing the watch, but the sleep tracker has kicked in on me while dozing in my recliner, and it seems accurate enough.

The only downsides for me:

Samsung Store is... bad. Very bad. Hard to find anything. Details on the app/watchface are lacking.

I'm using this watch with a OnePlus 6T and can't get Samsung Pay installed. There is a workaround floating around out there that involves sideloading an older version, then upgrading from within the Gear Android app, but that doesn't work anymore. Bummed about this. I really wanted to try out tap & pay on a magnetic swipe terminal. Oh, well.

All in all, this watch is definitely worth the price I paid. Glad I finally took the plunge.

author: Andre Glenn
title: Great Smartwatch
content:
This is a pretty cool smartwatch. I love that it looks like a watch (i.e. is round).  Someone looking at your wrist from afar would just assume that you're wearing a chronograph watch or a sports watch. Its barely bigger than the Movado Series 800 chronograph that I used to wear.  The rotating bezel is an example of great user interface design. I can quickly navigate through the widgets and apps. The abttery life is very good, I get close to 3 days of normal use.

People complain about the lack of Samsung apps, but what apps are really missing? Are you going to watch YouTube on a screen that is less than 2 inches wide? Are you going to be surfing the web on such a small screen?  Or send out tweet after tweet? If you need to send a lengthy response to a text message, would you really want to do that on a watch? You can with the Gear S3 but it seems that you'd more likely pull out your phone to o that. So given the concept of using the proper tool for the proper task, what's actually missing?

There's an endless selection of watchfaces, you have weather, reminders, alarms, access to your contacts, your texts, your email, and your calendar, You can use Samsung Pay with your watch. Samsung's fitness tools such as a step counter, heartbeat monitor, floor counter. You have access to the Samsung Health app with all of its workouts. You have an Altimeter and Barometer. There's a maps app, though I don't see myself trying too use a map on a screen this small. You can store pictures, and music on the watch.  You can leave your phone in a different room and still be connected to the watch as long as they're both connected to the same network. The Always On Display is neat if you want to always see a watchface so that it looks like you're wearing a regular watch.  Though the AOD versions of some of the watchfaces are not that great looking.

Some things don't work perfectly. For instance, the "Floors" counter often does not count flights of stairs that I've walked up. The Altimeter is probably a little off. When the watch reminds you to get active and suggest an activity (like a Torso Twist), it doesn't always notice that you've started the suggested activity. I haven't gone through all of the workouts that the phone has available to it, so I can't speak to how accurate the watch records them.

author: Kory
title: Buyer Beware - Bad Battery - Worse Customer Service
content:
First - I love the watch and use it for text alerts, to see who is calling without pulling my phone out of my pocket, control audio/music to my wireless headphones (paired thru my Galaxy S7 Edge), step counter, etc. Exactly what I wanted in a smart watch. I loved it.

I have enjoyed using my watch daily for ~14 months with good battery life throughout the day and would charge it on the OEM charger on my nightstand every night... then one day my battery life would drain almost 50% within just a couple hours with no change in use patterns or software or anything.

I contacted Samsung Customer Service to try to troubleshoot the problem - they had me ship it to their service center. They told me that it needed a software update, the back was cracked and needed repair, and that they needed to replace the battery. Then they notified me that my warranty expired just over a month ago and it would cost me ~$75 for the repairs.

After doing some research I found that it is fairly common for the battery to swell during charging and crack the back glass and cause the battery to drain rapidly.

If Samsung would have recognized the manufacturing defect and fixed the problem at their cost - it would have been an inconvenience but I would have forgiven all. However they stuck to the warranty and told me to pay up or they would return my watch un-repaired. Very disappointing.

author: Johnny_Amazon®
title: Beautiful, Rugged, Yet Versatile and Functional - Almost Perfect for Your Samsung Phone
content:
The last smart watch I bought before this one was the Samsung Gear S - Samsung Gear S SM-R750 (S/K) Curved Super AMOLED Smart Watch (Black) - International Version No Warranty - which I thought had the best combination of looks, price, and functionality. I have the 3G version which included a SIM slot for its own cell line in case you wanted to detach it from your Samsung phone and use it as a standalone phone. Therefore, this review is mainly between these two watches.

First off, let's talk about the aspects where the original Gear S wins over the S3. The original Gear S is noticeable lighter, and feels more comfortable around your wrist, especially if you have smaller wrists. The curved design of the Gear S also makes it easier to see the watch face, and easier to use - your presses and swipes feel easier and more natural. I also like the band which comes with the Gear S, as it makes wearing it and taking it off a much simpler, faster, and easier process - I can pretty much wear and take off the Gear S in about 1 second, whereas it would take me about 2-3 seconds to take off the S3, and about 5 seconds to put it on because you have to hook it into the hole, and then slide the tongue underneathe the two holding bands.

However, I prefer the S3 in these areas: It feels faster and snappier to use. Also, since it has newer technologies, the apps that come with it feels more modern and robust. Tizen has come a long way since the very first original Gear, and although it still has a long ways to go, at least you can see some slight improvements. Ultimately though, I feel Tizen is taking too long to progress, and will soon be forgotten, or relegated to being a smart watch OS only, and not something that can be used on phones. The screen of the Gear S3 feels brighter and more colorful, no doubt the progression of Samsung's watch OLED technology. The rotating bezel and extra button on the S3 also make using it easier, and gives it more functionality. Maybe it is just my watch, but I would like the bezel to rotate with more clamping force, as it feels too loose and easy to accidentally be moved. The watch face of the S3 looks and feels much more premium than the older S, as the metal parts make it look like a more expensive rugged watch, as opposed to the Gear S' more elegant 007/Dick Tracy spy watch style design. I also think the speaker on the S3 is just a tad louder than the Gear S. The S3 also has more and better watch faces than the Gear S.

In the end, I decided to keep both watches, for different occasions. The Gear S3 is my everyday watch, while the Gear S is more suited for a jog or something where you don't watch a big thick heavy watch to weigh you down.

title: Disgusted by this purchase.
content:
So after the first one finally died (Original review below) I bought another. As far as I can tell, I bought a new one but when it arrived, it's says "Certified refurb"...

Original review: This thing has plagued me since purchase. I wanted to love it so much and, at times, I did love it. Here is my journey:

-At first it had a problem staying in sync with my phone. Whenever it got separated, I had to reset the entire device to factory settings. An eventual update fixed that problem.

-The heart rate monitor stopped working. Still doesn't work. I didn't really care about this feature at first but then it became important to me. I miss it now that it's gone.

-Battery lasted for days when I bought it. Now, it won't last a twelve hour work day. Six hours, sometimes.

-After the latest update, I have to manually log into Samsung Health every couple of days. I love dialing verifications to prove I'm not a robot.

-It no longer tracks my steps. At all.

Other features still work great. Media, apps, controlling other devices, phone calls. I'm just frustrated. For a while, it was great. The last few months have been dogged with the loss of functionality.

author: Will K.
title: Somewhere Between Dumbwatch and Smartphone
content:
First and foremost, this is supposed to be a WATCH. That means this thing's main job is to tell TIME... But since we're also calling it a "SMARTwatch", shouldn't it at LEAST be able do everything the best "DUMBwatch" can do?

******************

I FORGOT... WHAT'S A WATCH, AGAIN?

Before we get ahead of ourselves, let's start with the basics -- the features that make a great watch. There are several optional features available in traditional watches and if this one's going to be SMARTER than average, I believe it should have MOST of these features straight out of the box.

A smartwatch should have (and prioritize) the following basic functions:

1. A full-featured Chronograph. Currently, the stopwatch feature only exists as a widget on the default watch face, rather than as a standalone watch mode. This means that if you customize the watch face, you'll lose your stopwatch.
2. A Timer. There should be a standalone mode to sound an alarm after a desired number of minutes pass. Currently, there is no built-in timer on the watch.
3. An Alarm. You should be able to efficiently set at least one alarm that will sound/vibrate at a specified time of day or week.
4. A World Clock. There should be a simple ability to switch between home time zone and a minimum of 2 other saved locales. Consider allowing a GMT hand/time.

Currently these key functions either don't exist at all on the watch or are separate apps that are not grouped in any logical fashion. (Currently there is an Alarm and a World Clock app but I believe they should be grouped logically and accessed more conveniently than any of the watch's "smart" features.)

SIDENOTE: I currently own a Citizen WR100 that can do all of the aforementioned. It was made like... 30 years ago and manages all these functions without the benefit of a CPU, RAM, or touch screens.
Despite the incredible advancements in technology since the manufacture of that watch, this 3rd generation Samsung "smartwatch" has been designed to perform far FEWER timekeeping functions than my 30-year-old "dumbwatch..."

How does that make sense?

******************

THE WATCH BAND

Before I start on the "smart" watch features, I have to mention the watch band.

You should know it's been reported by a significant number of users that the included silicon watch band causes friction burns; I've experienced a bit of it myself. It is also impossible (for me) to make it fit comfortably, as the clasp half of the strap is not long enough to keep the watch face centered on my 7.5" wrist.
The watch includes an optional shorter perforated half, but NOT a longer clasp half, so there's no way to center the clasp and watch face without over-tightening the band.

Although the band is silicone, the watch case is 316L Stainless Steel and appears well-made. Simply put, it should have been paired with a traditional and matching stainless steel band with removable links. Sure, it's more expensive to produce, but considering the number of people who have experienced discomfort and scarring from wearing the silicon band, it's far better to begin with a proper steel band and allow customization afterward if desired. If such a band cannot be provided with the watch, a matching band should at least be made available by Samsung for a nominal fee.

As of right now, it's only possible to acquire steel bands from a 3rd party, and only various leather, textile, and silicon bands can be purchased directly from Samsung. These bands have the same dimensions as the included silicon band, however, so if the original band doesn't fit properly, purchasing ANY replacement band from Samsung will only perpetuate your discomfort.

******************

SMARTWATCH FEATURES

Get ready to think wayyy outside the box...

You need to think of this watch as being DUMBER than a normal watch and SMARTER than a flip phone, but never knowing quite enough about watches or phones to do what you really want. At MOST, it's a wrist-borne relay point between you and your smartphone. It's like a middle[wo]man that allows you to:

1. Send txts or reply to messages from a preset list of allowed apps
2. Place and answer phone calls, mute the built-in microphone, and adjust the speaker volume with the bezel. (Perfect.)
3. Read notifications (from certain apps)
4. Continue playing music you've recently started on your phone, adjust the volume, and skip tracks with the bezel. (In my opinion, the bezel should control the volume, not skipping tracks. Who skips that many tracks without seeing the working playlist?)
5. Make payments via Samsung Pay
6. Et al.

It can collect biometrics intermittently for S Health as well, monitoring your steps, heart rate, and sleep efficiency. These features seem to work fairly well, but you may experience some discomfort if you allow the watch to collect heart rate data throughout the day. (The watch can get a bit warm/hot.)

******************

OOPS...

As smart as these features may be, the watch isn't good at doing ANY of them simultaneously... Btw, that includes telling TIME.
[Yes. You read that correctly. Just because you've got a watch, you should NOT expect it to tell time... It's 2018, ok? Things are different now.]

If you attempt to switch tasks or lower your arm in the midst of a reply, you are likely to lose your work. That adds up to a LOT of wasted life if you've started drafting your txts on a 1.25" screen...

You also cannot switch tasks during certain processes, like:

1. Taking phone calls.
During a call, a user cannot leave the call screen for any reason. And when I say "not for any reason", I literally mean that a person wearing this "watch" CANNOT CHECK THE TIME OR DATE, nor can they execute any other function during a call. So by design, the primary purpose of this product can't be realized while it attempts to be MORE than a basic watch; it literally CEASES to be a watch while you're taking a call!
Did I just buy a broken watch?
--------------------
When I first realized I couldn't read the time while staring at my $300 watch, I almost said THIS to the person I was talking to:
"Excuse me, do you have the time? I really SHOULD have it, but... apparently I don't."
I couldn't make my mouth say those ridiculous words, though. Instead, I did what Samsung expected:
I used my free hand to pull out my PHONE so I could use it like a WATCH while I talked into my WATCH like a PHONE...
--------------------
Do I really have to explain the magnitude of failure involved here? I hope not, because it HURTS MY BRAIN to even relive that moment. All I'll say is it's completely UNACCEPTABLE for such an advanced piece of technology to EVER SUCK THAT HARD.

1a.  If notifications come in during a call, don't expect to see them for more than half a second.
1b. And... if notifications come in during a call, don't even HOPE to reply.

2. During a workout, you're stuck with S Health on the screen. If you want to use a different feature or app, you've gotta end (not pause) your workout. But hey, at least it'll flash the time of day real quick when you wake the screen! That immediately makes S Health the best app on the watch!

******************

BUT WAIT -- THERE'S LESS

I think any good "smart" device should have strong app support to keep it relevant. Unfortunately, though, this watch lacks support from the major msg-based apps you use on a daily basis, like WhatsApp and Facebook Messenger, likely owing (in part) to the fact that it is built on the Linux Tizen platform, as opposed to the Android platform developers are already writing for in the Google Play Store. So without standalone apps, it is really difficult [read "impossible"] to respond to and keep track of any non-SMS msg thread.

For example...
Let's say you get a notification from Facebook Messenger and catch a glimpse of a truncated msg from your best friend... only to get 3 MORE Messenger notifications at once without time enough to read them all. The notifications disappear as each new msg comes in and you wind up missing so much of the thread that you just let your arm drop... defeated... to your side, as you wrestle out your phone to see WTF YOU JUST MISSED...

Sound stressful? Oh good... I've described it PERFECTLY.

******************

THE BOTTOM LINE

It's basically like this -- this device is barely DUMB enough to reliably be a watch. And it's barely SMART enough to reliably be a smartphone... In truth, it's neither watch nor smartphone; it's a clumsy, expensive, half-baked concept that makes this product fall miles behind the standard of quality you'd expect from Samsung.

I wish I could say better, because I really love Samsung products. In fact, I enjoy my Galaxy S8 phone so much that I recently got a Samsung NP940X5N laptop, and I love that product too. They're the best phone and computer I've ever had... But I can't say the same about this watch!

content: I love this thing. It does so much, and I keep discovering more things it does. I have a samsung galaxy note 8 and it pairs up with it seamlessly, and set up was super easy. author: Math Addict
title: Bad hardware, bad technical support
content:
I received my Gear S3 six weeks ago. Already I have two hardware problems - the rotating bezel sticks and requires considerable effort to turn and, yesterday, the speaker stopped working.

I contacted Samsung support and got some Indian chap who didn't know the product at all. When he asked for my serial number he couldn't tell me where to find it. I finally found the Gear Info screen and gave him the number and he claimed his system couldn't find it so he had to escalate me. He couldn't even forward me, he had to send me an email with a phone number.

So now I have to call a number to a woman with a very strong accent and loud noise behind her so I could barely understand her. I repeated all the information I gave the first guy and she makes me do a factory reset which wipes all my data. Obviously it didn't work so now they're going to send me an envelope to put my watch in. But they're having problems getting envelopes to people (probably because of the huge volume of people getting their watches fixed) so I'm going to be without my watch for a couple of weeks.

I used to think Samsung was a quality company, but I see they're not. I have a watch with mechanical issues within six weeks of purchase and a broken technical support system to deal with. I have a bad feeling they will return my watch unfixed and then claim it's outside the warranty. There's still another star I can remove.

Update: Although the start of the return process felt like it was being run by one man in his garage rather than a multi-national corporation, once I had got my watch back to Samsung the process was well handled. I received emails when the watch was received, started repair, suspended for lack of replacement parts, and when a new watch was shipped to me. I'll add a star back.

author: Whoaa Is Me
title: If I Could Give it ZERO Stars, I WOULD!
content: I bought this watch (ABOUT 11 MONTHS AGO) primarily as a fitness watch to replace a Fitbit that I had for a few years. At first, I was impressed with the rugged design and bulkiness of it. If feels like a darn tank on your wrist.  It has all the standard smartwatch junk that most smartwatches have.  Again, primarily a fitness watch.  So, I did the usual fitness things, hiked, jogged, the usual sweat causing activities. Then about 6 months later, it started randomly flickering. Didn't think anything of it.  Two months after that, it starting dimming.  A month ago, starting doing both on rotation to the point that the watch was useless. As you can see, I'm a pretty tolerant person to walk around with a flickering watch for a couple of months. Finally had enough in Aug and notified Samsung that my watch might be faulty. Under 12 months, it was still covered under warranty. They sent me a label, sent it in. Waiting about 10 days to be told that my watch was not under warranty due to "water damage". I've NEVER submerged the watch as I was a bit paranoid to begin with of it's "water resistance" for a $300 techy watch.  Only water that touched that watch was sweat on my arm.  So was informed from Samsung that they had "GREAT NEWS", they could swap it out for only $230. I told them to shove it. They said they'd send it back.  Now I have a $300 paperweight shaped like a crappy watch.  NEVER will buy a stupid Samsung watch again.

content:

Price was good although I found a better deal in Kuwait (since I live there) but overall I was impressed and the delivery was amazing since I received it right before I checked out from the hotel although it was planned to be delivered to the locker after I leave but I received it earlier.

author: Eddie
title: The battery will instantly drain after one year of use
content:
I USED to love this watch when I got it last year. So many neat features and it connects so well to my Samsung device and it's a fun way to answer phone calls. Its sturdy, its waterproof.

But now the battery drains instantly where it used to last all day. I charge it to 100 overnight, put it on, it's at 90 in 30 minutes. If you leave it on your desk on power saving mode and don't touch it for 3-4 hours, I promise it will be dead or at around 10%. Just in the time of writing these two paragraphs it has dropped from 92 to 89%. Its jaw dropping to look down and see its dropped another percent EVERY time you look at it. Ridiculous.

Its not just me. If you Google "gear s3 battery drain" you'll see nearly EVERY owner of this watch eventually deals with this. Their customer service will not help, they just tell you to pay to have it repaired or replaced.

Cool watch, I've gotten good use out of it for a year and a half. But for only a good year and a half of use, this is not worth the price. Not at all.

author: C. Costa
title: Fragile and disposable! (Updated)
content:
Edit: See update below!

(Original Review: March 2018)
My only 2 gripes are that there are so few native apps, and no Google assistant.

The watch looks and runs fantastically, I get great battery life. The display is the best smartwatch display on the market. The speaker and microphone works great! I swapped out the rubber band for a black stainless steel one, and it looks good on my wrist.

Samsung Pay on a watch feels like magic every time I use it, that MST tech from Samsung is pretty damn cool. It can fall back on NFC too.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Nice Device, Poor software Functionality
content: I was very excited to receive my Samsung Gear S3, which I purchased for use with my new Samsung Galaxy S8 cell phone.  The watch is very nice to look at, the AMOLED screen is awesome, it's a bit heavy, but the issue I had was overall functionality of the software. Unfortunately much of the utility that I had hoped to realize from this device was not materialize.  My personal opinion is that the Samsung S Health software is not yet to the point of really being used for anything more than outdoor running and counting steps (outside the GPS probably does fine, but indoor track running or walking does not work well).  At $350, this is a very expensive pedometer.  I know, I know, you are saying to me to me right now "Hey, it is supposed to help you reduce some of the hands on that is required to interact with your phone, email, and messaging!", and it does some of that very nicely.  The notifications are very good and I did like being able to read email through the watch and see my text messages, including attached pictures.  However, a large part of my daily routine is swimming, walking, lifting and other physical activities throughout  the week and this watch does not really improve my workout tracking.  In fact, It took me backwards from a capability standpoint.  For example, for my morning stretching, I had to use my phone to start and stop this activity.  Then it is off to swim for 30 to 40 minutes, oops, that activity has to be started and stopped on the phone.  That is unless, you want to track your different activities as an "other workout".  Not much value there for me.  I returned the Gear S3 and took out my 2 year old Garmin Vivoactive and while that watch is nor perfect by any stretch, I can start and stop all of my activities from my wrist and I don't have to lug my cell phone with me.  Additionally, I was not going to get the S3 with the cell service, I didn't see the point in having more cost in this very expensive solution and that option will not change haw the different activities have to be initiated, on the cell phone.
